A polynomial $f \in R[X]$ with coefficients in a unique factorization domain $R$ is called primitive if the greatest common divisor of all its coefficients is 1, or equivalently, if $
u_p(f) = 0$ for all prime elements $p \in R$.

An algebraic subset of \(\bar{K}^{n}\) defined over \(K\) is the set of common zeros in \(\bar{K}^{n}\) of the polynomials belonging to a subset \(E\) of the polynomial ring \(K[X]=K\left[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right]\). It is denoted as \(V(E)\).
Does the concept of a/an Primitive Polynomial need to be defined for a definition of a/an Algebraic subset to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The definition of an algebraic subset involves the set of common zeros of polynomials from a subset of a polynomial ring over a field K. This definition focuses on the zeros of any polynomials in the ring K[X1, ..., Xn], without any specific requirements on the nature of these polynomials beyond their belonging to the polynomial ring.

On the other hand, a primitive polynomial is defined specifically with respect to its coefficients and their greatest common divisor within a unique factorization domain. This concept is particularly relevant in the context of polynomial rings over integral domains where factorization properties are important, such as ensuring the polynomial is not divisible by any prime element of the ring.

The concept of a primitive polynomial does not intersect with the requirements for defining an algebraic subset. The algebraic subset is concerned with the zeros of polynomials and does not require the polynomials to be primitive. Therefore, the definition of a primitive polynomial is not necessary for the definition of an algebraic subset to make sense.
